title: Ecosystems
blurb: Discover how living and non-living parts work together in ecosystems, and how habitats, populations, and communities stay in balance.

vocab.definition: All the living and non-living parts of a place that interact
The natural home where a living thing finds food, water, shelter, and space
All the members of one kind of living thing in the same place
All the different living things that share the same area
The living parts of an ecosystem, like plants and animals
The non-living parts of an ecosystem, like sunlight, water, air, and soil
Parts or conditions that affect an ecosystem (biotic or abiotic)
The role a living thing plays in its habitat, including what it eats and where it lives
When living things depend on each other and their environment to survive
A living thing, like a plant, that makes its own food
A living thing that gets energy by eating plants or animals
An animal that eats only plants
A living thing that breaks down dead matter and returns nutrients to the soil
A network that shows how energy moves through many connected feeding paths
A single path that shows how energy moves from plants to animals
An animal that hunts and eats other animals
An animal that is hunted and eaten by a predator
An animal that eats only other animals
An animal that eats both plants and animals
An animal that eats dead animals it did not hunt
Tiny living things too small to see without a microscope that help break things down
Materials in food or soil that help living things grow
How energy moves from the sun to plants and then to animals
Something that controls how many organisms can live in a habitat (like water or space)
The largest number of one kind that an environment can support
A feature or behavior that helps an organism survive in its habitat
When organisms need the same resource like food, water, or space
A close relationship between two different kinds of organisms (can help, harm, or not affect)
A large area covered chiefly with trees and undergrowth; a common ecosystem type

teachingNotes: Start with a local ecosystem picture. Sort items into biotic vs abiotic. Show how a habitat provides food, water, shelter, and space. Build from individual → population → community → ecosystem. Use a simple food web to model interdependence. Ask 'What if?' changes (less rain, new species) to discuss balance.
